figures.description: Production‑possibility frontier (PPF) of a country used for Questions 5 and 6. Concave curve between consumer goods and producer goods, with labeled points V, W, X, Y and Z. Points on the curve (V, W, X, Y) show full‑employment combinations; Z lies outside the original frontier and is attainable only with technological progress or increased resources.

Short‑run cost schedule for Questions 15 and 16. Output per day Q (units): 20, 30, 40, 50, 60, 70, 80. Fixed cost (FC) per day: ₦60 for all outputs. Total cost (TC) per day (₦): 100, 120, 130, 135, 150, 170, 190. Average total cost ATC = TC/Q. Average variable cost AVC = (TC − FC)/Q.

instructions.text: In each of questions 1 to 50, choose the option that best answers the question or completes the statement.

questions.question: The price of a good rises from ₦5 to ₦8 and the quantity demanded falls from 200 to 190 units. Over this price range, the demand curve is
questions.explanation: Arc elasticity: \(E_d = \dfrac{\Delta Q}{\Delta P} \times \dfrac{P_1+P_2}{Q_1+Q_2} = \dfrac{-10}{3} \times \dfrac{5+8}{200+190} \approx -0.11\). Since \(|E_d| < 1\), demand is inelastic (but not perfectly), i.e. fairly inelastic.

questions.question: In economic analysis, a statement is said to be normative if it
questions.explanation: Normative statements express **value judgements** about what ought to be.

questions.question: Utility is the satisfaction derived from
questions.explanation: Utility is the satisfaction obtained from **consuming** goods and services.

questions.question: If there is an increase in demand without a corresponding increase in supply, there will be a

options.text: shift in supply curve to the right
shift in demand curve to the left

questions.explanation: Higher demand with fixed supply moves equilibrium to a **higher price**.

questions.question: Using the production possibility curve of a country (figure Econ2003_PPF_VWXZ), an improvement in technology will enable the country to produce at
questions.explanation: Point Z lies **outside** the original PPF and becomes attainable only after technological progress or increased resources.

questions.question: If the country is currently producing at point Y on the same PPF, it can increase production of producer goods by moving to
questions.explanation: Moving along the PPF towards **W** represents more producer goods and fewer consumer goods.

questions.question: In a table (not shown), the price of commodity Y is ₦2 and that of X is ₦1 while the individual has an income of ₦12. Determine the combination of the two commodities the individual should consume to maximize his utility.
questions.explanation: The optimum bundle satisfies \(MU_x/P_x = MU_y/P_y\) and \(P_x X + P_y Y = 12\). The marginal utilities from the original table are needed to compute this; they are not legible in the scan.

questions.question: When two variables are positively related, the graph of the relationship
questions.explanation: A positive relationship means that as one variable increases, the other increases; the curve therefore **slopes upward**.

questions.question: For an inferior good, a decrease in real income leads to

options.text: an outward shift of the demand curve
an inward shift of the demand curve

questions.explanation: Inferior‑good demand **increases** when income falls.

questions.question: In a planned economy the emphasis is on
questions.explanation: Centrally planned economies rely on **public ownership and central decisions**.

questions.question: Price elasticity of supply is a ratio of the change in

options.text: quantity supplied to the change in demand
original quantity to a change in new quantity
quantity supplied to the change in price
price to the change in quantity supplied

questions.explanation: By definition: \(E_s = \dfrac{\%\Delta Q_s}{\%\Delta P}\).

questions.question: The long‑run average‑cost curve is called a planning curve because it shows what happens to costs when

options.text: different sizes of plants are built
a bigger size of plant is built

questions.explanation: The LRAC envelope connects the lowest short‑run AC for different **plant sizes**.

questions.question: Imperfect market is characterized by

options.text: a large number of buyers and sellers
perfect mobility of factors of production

questions.explanation: Monopoly/oligopoly involve **few sellers facing many buyers**.

questions.question: Short‑run period in production is a period for a firm to be able to change its
questions.explanation: In the short run, only **variable inputs** can be adjusted.

questions.question: Using the table in figure Econ2003_CostTable, the average total cost (ATC) at 30 units of output is
questions.explanation: At \(Q = 30\), \(TC = 120\). Thus \(ATC = TC/Q = 120/30 = ₦4.00\). None of the options shows ₦4.00, so the printed options appear inconsistent with the data.

questions.question: From the same table, at 60 units of output the average variable cost (AVC) is
If the demand curve facing a firm is sharply downward‑sloping, the firm is likely to be

options.text: a monopolistic competitor as it can have a limited influence on price
an oligopolist as it can collude with other firms to have some influence on price
a monopolist and can have considerable influence on price

questions.explanation: A monopolist faces the entire market demand and therefore a **steep downward‑sloping demand curve**.

questions.question: A normal supply curve is usually positively sloped

options.text: because the relationship between supply and price is negative
because supply and price is negative
since price and demand is negative
since price and supply is positive

questions.explanation: As price increases, firms are willing to supply more; the **direct relationship** makes the curve slope upward.

questions.question: The best method of production in an under‑populated country is
questions.explanation: Where labour is scarce relative to capital, **capital‑intensive** production is appropriate.

questions.question: Insurance companies, pension and provident funds and unit trusts are all examples of
questions.explanation: They are **non‑bank financial intermediaries**.

questions.question: For a firm, value added can be defined as the difference between the

options.text: value of its output and the cost of production
value of its output and inputs purchased from other firms

questions.explanation: Value added = \(\text{Sales value} − \text{value of intermediate inputs}\).

questions.question: Securities are described as listed when they are

options.text: bought and sold purely for development purposes
traded on a recognized stock market

questions.explanation: Listed securities are **quoted on a stock exchange**.

questions.question: The commercial banks differ from non‑bank financial institutions because they
questions.explanation: Only commercial banks provide **chequeable demand deposits**.

questions.question: Inflation that is usually associated with periods of trade boom is
questions.explanation: A trade boom increases aggregate demand, leading to **demand‑pull inflation**.

questions.question: The term “Near Money” is best described as

options.text: a financial asset that is convertible to cash
a financial instrument that is readily convertible to cash
government financial instrument that is convertible to cash
time deposits with low interest rates

questions.explanation: **Near money** comprises assets that are quickly and easily convertible into cash.

questions.question: The distinguishing characteristic between the money market and the capital market lies in whether the

options.text: funds mobilized are private or public
debt instruments provided are long‑term or short‑term
securities are in debentures or ordinary shares

questions.explanation: Money markets deal with **short‑term** funds; capital markets with **long‑term** funds.

questions.question: If Nigeria’s composite price index in 1999 was 140.03 and 144.05 in 2000, the rate of inflation in 2000 was approximately
questions.explanation: Inflation ≈ \(\frac{144.05 - 140.03}{140.03} \times 100 ≈ 2.87\%\). The printed options do not match this exactly.

questions.question: The monetary‑control instrument most effectively used by the Central Bank of Nigeria is the
questions.explanation: Open‑market operations provide the **main day‑to‑day tool** for controlling money supply.

questions.question: The major objectives of a revenue allocation formula in a country is to

options.text: share revenue between the public and private sectors
ensure the financial viability of the country
share revenue between the different tiers of government
divert revenue from areas of surplus to areas of need

questions.explanation: Nigeria’s revenue‑allocation formula divides revenue among **federal, state and local governments**.

questions.question: The effectiveness of devaluation as a solution to a balance‑of‑payments problem depends on the

options.text: value of visible and invisible goods
value of invisible items of both domestic and foreign trades

questions.explanation: Devaluation improves the BOP if the demand for exports and imports is **sufficiently elastic** (Marshall–Lerner condition).

questions.question: The IBRD as an international monetary institution is concerned with the

options.text: financing of private business in member nations
development of infrastructure in member nations
improvement of trade among member nations

questions.explanation: The IBRD (World Bank) finances **development and infrastructure** projects.

questions.question: An advantage of the sole‑proprietorship over the partnership form of business organization is that it

options.text: enjoys limited liability for debt in the event of failure
its existence is limited by an individual’s lifespan
relies on the decision of friends to succeed
has conflict in management virtually non‑existent

questions.explanation: Single ownership means **little or no management conflict**.

questions.question: The distinction between capital and recurrent expenditure lies in the

options.text: nature of the goods and services to be provided

questions.explanation: Capital expenditure creates/maintains **long‑term assets**; recurrent covers **regular services and wages**.

questions.question: Under a floating exchange‑rate regime, the determinant of the exchange rate is the

options.text: demand for and supply of foreign goods
an Act of the National Assembly

questions.explanation: Floating exchange rates are determined by **market demand and supply for foreign exchange**.

questions.question: To compare the standard of living among nations, the most widely used economic indicator is
questions.explanation: Real **per‑capita income** adjusts for inflation and population.

questions.question: The labour force of a country can be determined by examining the
questions.explanation: The labour force is essentially the **working‑age population**.

questions.question: Two basic features common to an industry are

options.text: similarity of products and production processes
similarity of products and sources of raw materials
production processes and sources of capital
sources of capital and labour supply

questions.explanation: An industry groups firms producing **similar products using related processes**.

questions.question: A country is said to be over‑populated when

options.text: there are too many able‑bodied men and women in the country
the resources are more than enough to cater for the population
the size of the population is greater than the annual budget
the resources are inadequate to cater for the population

questions.explanation: Over‑population occurs when **resources are insufficient relative to population**.

questions.question: When a union is composed of workers with the same skill, it is called
questions.explanation: A **craft union** consists of workers of the same trade (e.g. carpenters).

questions.question: An adverse environmental impact of the petroleum industry on the economy is
questions.explanation: **Oil spills** cause pollution and ecological damage.

questions.question: An important factor hindering the rapid development of the industrial sector in Nigeria is

options.text: the dominance of the oil sector

questions.explanation: Poor electricity, roads, ports etc. are a key constraint on industrial growth.

questions.question: The demand for labour is an example of
questions.explanation: Labour is demanded because of the **goods and services it helps to produce**.

questions.question: The major role of multi‑national companies in the petroleum industry in Nigeria is
questions.explanation: Multinationals typically handle both **exploration/production and marketing**.

questions.question: Fixing the prices of agricultural products can be a problem because of the
questions.explanation: Weather and pests make **farm output variable**, so a fixed price may cause big surpluses or shortages.

questions.question: Occupational mobility as applied to factors of production means the case by which

options.text: factors can be transferred from one place to another
factors can be transferred from one form of use to another
resources can be transferred from one place to another
resources can be transferred from one form to another

questions.explanation: Occupational mobility refers to movement of a factor (especially labour) **between different occupations/uses**.

questions.question: The labour force of a country can be determined by examining the
questions.explanation: Again, **age structure** determines the size of the working‑age population.

questions.question: Two basic features common to an industry are

options.text: similarity of products and production processes
similarity of products and sources of raw materials
production processes and source of capital
sources of capital and labour supply

questions.explanation: Firms in the same industry produce **similar products using related processes**.

questions.question: A country is said to be over‑populated when

options.text: there are too many able‑bodied men and women in the country
the resources are more than enough to cater for the population
the size of the population is greater than the annual budget
the resources are inadequate to cater for the population

questions.explanation: Over‑population means the **population is too large relative to available resources**.

questions.question: When a union is composed of workers with the same skill, it is called
questions.explanation: A **craft union** organizes workers by skill or trade.

questions.question: An adverse environmental impact of the petroleum industry on the economy is
questions.explanation: Oil spillage causes **pollution** and long‑term environmental degradation.
